docs.lead_paragraph: AFTER watching tobacco use among teen-agers increase in West Hartford, a town councilman became determined to do something to prevent other young people from taking up the habit. The determination of the councilman, John L. Bonee 3d, a lawyer who works with teen-agers in Juvenile Matters Court in Hartford, turned into the passage of a town law that prohibits the sale of tobacco to people under 18 years old. The minimum age for the rest of the state is 16. As with the purchase of alcohol, teen-agers must now show identification before they can buy tobacco in West Hartford. Anyone caught selling tobacco to a minor could be fined $100.

headline.main: YOUTHS QUESTION EFFECTIVENESS OF WEST HARTFORD TOBACCO BAN

docs.lead_paragraph: The number of emotionally disturbed patients being treated and involuntarily admitted at New York's municipal hospitals has increased sharply since a just-released mental patient was charged with killing two people aboard a Staten Island ferryboat, city officials said yesterday. Psychiatric units in municipal hospitals have become so overcrowded since the July 7 attack, the officials said, that patients are being transferred in buses to state psychiatric hospitals outside the city. Dr. Luis Marcos, head of mental health services for the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, attributed the increase to ''caution'' and ''defensiveness'' being exercised by psychiatrists following what the city and the state said was the ''premature'' and ''medically inappropriate'' release of the suspect, Juan J. Gonzalez, from the psychiatric emergency room of Presbyterian Hospital on July 5. #2 Days in Emergency Room Mr. Gonzalez, 43 years old, had been kept in the psychiatric emergency room at Presbyterian for two days before his release after the hospital had failed to have him admitted to another hospital. Presbyterian Hospital officials contend that the hospital's treatment of Mr. Gonzalez was appropriate.

headline.main: PSYCHIATRIC TREATMENT SURGING SINCE FERRY KILLINGS
